summary: Small-time crook Clyde Barrow (Warren Beatty) tries to steal a car and winds up with its owner's daughter, dissatisfied small-town girl Bonnie Parker (Faye Dunaway). Their crimes quickly spiral from petty theft to bank robbery, but tensions between the couple and the other members of their gang--hapless driver C.W. (Michael J. Pollard), Clyde's suave older brother Buck (Gene Hackman) and Buck's flibbertigibbet wife, Blanche (Estelle Parsons) --could destroy them all.

reviews.content: 60% rating ... I thought it was a decent film that told the story of the infamous Bonnie & Clyde. Loved the end scene.

While it's far from perfect, Arthur Penn's Bonnie and Clyde is a seminal film in the development of the American New Wave of movies.  Set during the American Depression, Bonnie (Faye Dunaway) and Clyde (Warren Beatty) roam the countryside in search of easy prey to rob, creating a trail of violence and death.  The film made stars of Beatty and Dunaway, who are both excellent, and served as a springboard for actors like Gene Hackman and Gene Wilder, and features interesting and complex characters, a strong score, great period details, and some impressive cinematography.  If there are criticisms to be made, it would involve the periodically erratic editing which by today's standards feels dated, some bizarre lighting, and the fact that the protagonists consistently (at least until the final scene) make highly improbable escapes.  All in all, it is a solid offering from Penn that should be seen for its historical cinematic importance.

An overly glamorous portrayal of the protagonists; Bonnie Parker was no Faye Dunaway, and Clyde Barrow was no Warren Beaty.  The film was made to capitalize on the box office appeal of the two leads and served up for-the-time shocking gore to its audience.  Five years later The Godfather would up the ante with the toll booth scene.  The viewer has to put one's self in the shoes of its 1967 audience; at the time millions of older adults would have followed the newspaper and radio accounts of this couple's exploits.  B&C was an updated, Technicolor version of a formula that had made Hollywood tons of cash going back to the days of Jimmy Cagney, George Raft, and Humphrey Bogart, but with more realistic-looking blood.
Classic. Faye Dunaway is stunning

This film is one of the best of all 1960's movies. A very well developed & extremely well acted film. Quite fast paced considering when the film was made. The film shows an older, more attractive Bonnie and Clyde than what is seen in history. It's interesting watching the the couple and their crew throughout the movie battle the law and each other. It's a very watchable film from start to finish.
The movie was kind of in a hurry and the story is so simplified that it seemed easy cheesy..

[10/1/20]: It actually sucks. It got better toward the end, but wow. Use of violence at time was bold, exploration of male protagonist with sexual disfunction was unique for the time as well.
[6/29/22]: Yeah I do remember not really being fond of it. Can respect its influence, for sure, but as a movie I guess it just didn't click. I also remember not really enjoying Warren Beatty; compared with Dick Tracy and The Parallax View, this is definitely the one I liked him in least.

Humorous and ingenious. Lighthearted and dark. Adventurous and ambivalent. It is rare to see the late 1920s era portrayed in such a light and free-spirited manner, as opposed to the "serious" climate that usually tents over (especially during and before the time the movie was made). Bonnie & Clyde is indeed a drama and a thriller, but it's also a comedy. I found myself smiling through a large portion of it, and it mainly has to do with the fun nature of the characters. The performances were good, notably Faye Dunaway who was vivacious. The cinematography was good too. The ending gave me mixed feelings however, as it was expected and not creative, and also seemed rushed–albeit in harmony with the pace of the movie.

A fast paced, influential, and nearly perfect film in the crime genre, "Bonnie and Clyde" stands as one of the best movies of all time and a definitive film of its time. Acting was great and the story was compelling, giving the characters a very human touch that seems to be missing from many movies nowadays. The action was also incredibly great for its time, so much so that I think it still holds up fairly well to this day. It also has one of my absolute favourite endings in cinema history, and I think it's one that is extremely memorable and used to this day. My one main concern is that it isn't nearly as accurate as it probably could've been, and I think that making it a bit longer could've improved on some of the issues. Overall, a great film that still holds extremely well today and cements itself as an all-time classic, leaving behind a loud bang that change cinema history forever.

Although it's still hailed as the best movie about notorious lovers Bonnie and Clyde, this film is far from good. The acting is mediocre and the characters are unlikable, the story is messy and fails to follow a linear timeline, and the ending was unsatisfactory. The positive reviews and high ratings are misleading.
A very faithful adaption of Bonnie and Clyde as characters, but not the most faithful when its comes to some of the historical accuracy.
Blobbo not approve glorification ruthless behavior.

Historically inaccurate for no justifiable reason on many counts, not funny like other reviewers claim, and I would argue it was inappropriate to paint them in such a positive light. However, it was wise that the film went beyond just bank robberies to show some actual living, like arguments and pastimes. The plot did feel dragged out though, the way they and the mechanic met was a bizarre choice, some dialogue was poor whilst other scenes relied on weird facial expressions, Bonnie in particular wasn't believable at times, Gene Wilder gave an awful performance and didn't need to be there, and Blanche was extremely annoying. However, the shootouts, getaway driving, and ending sequence made for excellent action, the performances from Warren Beatty and Gene Hackman were well done, the cinematography, editing, and visual effects were solid for the time, the sets/props/costumes looked the part, and the soundtrack was appropriate and slightly catchy.

I am not sure whether I can add to the commentators who have talked about how good Bonnie and Clyde is, but I'll have a go. I didn't see Bonnie and Clyde until quite recently, and I can completely understand the film's reputation as it is a fantastic film. It is very well made, with crisp cinematography and a superb period recreation. The violence here is not cartoony, it is very violent and shocking, as seen in the ending which I also found quite affecting. Arthur Penn directs beautifully, there is a compelling story, a slick pace and a cracking script with some of the most important and sharpest dialogue in any film of the '60s. I was amazed by the last scene with Bonnie and her mother, it was a scene that is very chilling but also one that resonates emotionally too. And the acting I have no qualms with. Gene Hackman is wonderful as is Estelle Parsons as a somewhat annoying character. Also Gene Wilder makes a brief but funny appearance. But the film belongs to Warren Beatty and Faye Dunnaway, who actually become the characters rather than just playing them. Overall, a fantastic film and one of the best and most important of its decade. 10/10 Bethany Cox
It's a beautifully shot, very well directed movie, Dunaway and Beatty are simply glorious. The story on the other hand, had uneven pacing, could have used a very needed tonic to perk things up a bit.
The most infamous outlaw couple gets their time to shine on the big screen both actors have great chemistry which makes for quite an entertaining And action packed love story with a tragic ending

Sex(ual Frustration) & Violence across the 1930s American heartland with Warren Beaty and Faye Dunaway as iconic bank robbing duo Bonnie and Clyde. 

Pelts along at a cracking pace, with great action sequences, and in particular charismatic performances and chemistry from the two leads. Faye Dunaway is a knock-out as Bonnie, especially THAT pose with the cigar and tommy-gun. 

In amoungst the action there is some commentary on the notion of attaining fame through crime, with Bonnie and Clyde attaining folk hero and modern day Robin Hood status with the public. The film unashamedly glamorises the criminal element and violence on film and therefore was quite controversial in its day -  but it's so entertaining it's hard to resist.

A cornerstone of the "New Hollywood" period, Bonnie and Clyde is exceptional not just for its role in cinematic history, but also as a popcorn-munching Saturday Night adventure. If you want a deep-dive into the real eponymous characters, I recommend LPOTL's podcast three-part series, if you want the 111 minute cavalcade of entertainment, watch this movie. Clyde Barrow (Warren Beatty) leads the "Barrow Gang" through Texas and the Great Plains of the Midwest, robbing everything from banks to corner stores. Bonnie (Faye Dunaway), is his partner in crime and love of his life — it's fitting that she catches him in flagrante attempting to boost her mother's car. The titular couple has become a reference in their own right, even if they actually weren't all that great of criminals. That being said, Clyde was allegedly a fantastic driver, which were showcased in the film with many a car chase scene — how these cars going fifty or more miles an hour on nothing thicker than bicycle wheels didn't constantly flip over is beyond me. C.W. Moss (Michael J. Pollard), Buck Barrow (Dustin Hoffman), and Blanche Barrow (Estelle Parsons, who took away the only acting Oscar from the film) round out the gang. Crime was different in the 1930s, as in significantly easier to pull-off, as is epitomized during the scene where Buck shouts "We're the Barrow Gang!" to the frozen bank customers and staff, even raising his mask inches from the guard's nose and stating, "remember this face" (para) thereafter. The film was revolutionary in its depiction of sexuality — the painfully handsome Clyde has impotence issues — and violence. Early on, there is a grotesque scene where Clyde shoots a banker in the face as the victim jumps on the side of the getaway car. Later, a shoot-‘em-up style firefight with the police in Iowa kind of brings you back into the danger this world permits — I found it comical that the police arrive and just start blasting away. Most notable, however, has to be the final scene. The embarrassed (and legendary) Texas Ranger, Frank Hamer (Denver Pyle), takes a cohort of lawmen and fills our gorgeous couple full of lead long after they've stopped flopping around the ground and car like fish. Youth can't be leaving the theaters thinking the criminals get away with it, no matter how much we may be rooting for them. Hamer left a message — and a scene — that has gone down in history. Bonnie and Clyde is a cinephile's staple and a glimpse into a Hollywoodified period-piece on the Dust Bowl, Great Depression, and two American legends.
When you are in the mood for some old true crime, this one has all the classic tropes to make for good entertainment
Enjoyable, worthy of being called a classic, although the last scene ended like in a way that is not as satisfying as Chris Nolan's.
man they're such awful criminals but the ending got me ngl
Funny, original, and spellbound!!!!!!!!!!!!!
Amusing characters, but not quite The A-Team. The real Bonnie & Clyde murdered 13 people while robbing mostly small businesses during The Great Depression for a grand total of less than 1500 USD.
A classic in crime drama showing violence for what it is.
A classic. Dunaway and Beatty make fall in love with the bad guys and you’ll actually hope they escape law enforcement .

Easily one of the top on screen chemistries in Hollywood history. Supporting characters seemed stock but it's to be expected from the time. Wildly entertaining ride but at times doesn't elevate beyond an archetypal genre film.

I really enjoyed this telling of the story. It's a Bonnie story about Clyde having performance anxiety. Accurate reprisal of the key facts and some brilliant acting from all the madcap characters we meet along the way. A film that has aged so well. Bangin.

Characters in the movie are portrayed very well. When Bonnie's mother told her with the most serious face that she wouldn't live too long - that was the strongest moment, as Bonnie, a happy-go-lucky person, has realized that she was right.

The movie that changed cinema still holds up to this day.  Its one of the best movies of the 1960's.  It's exciting, suspenseful, shocking, heartbreaking, gruesome, funny and makes you care about the anti-heroes.  The two main leads are excellent.
One of the funniest and most entertaining crime films I've ever seen!!

The movie tells the interesting story about the infamous crime couple Bonnie and Clyde. Even though there were some inaccuracies, like them capturing the officer and taking pictures with him, they do tell a compelling story that personally, I never knew about. This is a Hollywood Classic that still stands pretty well today.

The heavily influential rebellious picture, that Jack Warner hated so much, has not aged since 1967. Numerous techniques pioneered in this movie, such as sound bridges, are commonly used in Hollywood blockbusters to this days.

AFI 100 Greatest Films - #27: I couldn't say how historically accurate (I am guessing liberties were taken) this stylish portrayal of the titular figures were, but I can say I found Ms. Dunaway mesmerizing and couldn't look away. The action was exciting and there was even some comedy blended in to offer something different than what I expected. I am not sure how much this film has to "say" but there are definitely films with much more to "say" that haven't held my attention as well.
Something about Bonnie and Clyde sticks.
The focus is off and it rewrites reality to glorify the evil.
An unexpected tale that is funny and refreshing.
It opened movies to sex and violence, influencing a generation of filmmakers more than any other movie, but it succeeded because it treated honestly and heartily his characters.
It's overrated and fails in comparison to more recent Bonnie and Clyde films to date
Gene Hackman is brilliant.

Another much-celebrated movie I can't see as a classic. The direction and editing are what truly shine, while the characterizations feel dated and a little too heavy handed. It all may have worked in its time, and is still a watchable movie, but I couldn't be bothered to give a damn.

Bonnie and Clyde treats its story, particularly the dynamic between its two main characters, with a fantastic level of sophistication and keeps a relatively healthy balance between Hollywood revisionism and true contemporary perspectives. (4/5)

It's hard to imagine a world where the concept of anti-heroes is not mainstream. Sure gangster films starring a sympathetic James Cagney were popular in the 1930s but this 1967 classic changed the face of American cinema and influenced a whole generation of filmmakers. Watching the film in the context of working through all the Best Picture nominees I realize just how different and groundbreaking this film was compared to the entertainment that came before it as compared to a dull slog like The Sand Pebbles (1966) or Doctor Dolittle (1967) it is positively electrifying and avant-garde. While it may not have the impact on the younger generation that it had in 1967 and some elements of it appear outdated it is an important cultural artifact and still provides some form of exhilaration.

Small town waitress Bonnie Parker, Faye Dunaway, meets and falls in love with bank robber Clyde Barrow, Warren Beatty, when he tries to steal her mother's car and soon the two are shacked up together and serve as partners in crime. Initially unsuccessful as bank robbers their business begins to pick up when they bring a driver on board in the form of the innocent C.W. Moss, Michael J. Pollard, in addition to Barrow's brother Buck, Gene Hackman, and his wife Blanche, Estelle Parsons, who immediately clashes with Parker. The group become nationwide celebrities through self promotion and enjoy their crime sprees even as they face threats from law enforcement. They are eventually shot to death in a bloody massacre by the police pursuing after one of their closest allies betrays them due to his belief that they are a negative influence on his innocent relative.

I must admit that I was rather shocked how quickly the film jumped into it's plot as usually with a film from this time period it takes at least an hour to lay out who the characters are at what the main conflict of the film will be. Not so in this film as we see our two protagonists meet, fall in love and begin robbing banks together within a matter of minutes. It takes a little while longer for Buck and Blanche to become involved but even so the disgruntlement of law enforcement and the effect of the media on their lives is seen early on in the film and from there it doesn't let up. This odd cast of characters spend their time stealing money and riding away in a rundown car in a fit of glee and we get to see all of that joy and excitement as they peel off down back roads and roll around in the back of the car. You are drawn into their breathless excitement and enjoyment because they have the gall to begin shooting people and stealing money without a second thought, they don't need to have their audience really get to know them over time because their characters are clearly established in the space of seconds. Arthur Penn knew exactly what he was doing by having this crazy couple come together immediately and audiences lapped up this change of pace.

Many will remember Dunaway, looking flawless, strolling into a bank and brandishing a gun and fortunately there are several scenes that give her an opportunity to do just that thing but deeper emotional depths are revealed. When she finally sees her mother again after so long away from her she is able to display all of the ambivalence and fear that she has kept below the surface during her time with the confident Barrow. The expression of pain on her face after facing her mother's cool, emotionless rejection of her romantic ideals is quite touching as the girl who puts on a "sexy" Southern drawl and seems to be forever posing has her humanity brought forth. Beatty is less interesting as the rather more straightforward Barrow as while he gets the job done he is ultimately not what you remember about the film. Parsons' Best Supporting Actress win is rather perplexing as she gives a hammy, hysterical performance that does not hint at the range that come with Rachel, Rachel (1968) while Hackman is typically brilliant as the rowdy Buck.

This is one that you must absolutely watch as it had an undeniable impact on the development of films in the late 1960s into the 1970s and still stands up today.
A instant classic and achievement in filmmaking.  Only reason I'm not giving a perfect review is because it should've been 30 extra minutes.  Warren Beatty cannot do anything wrong

The outrageous criminal love couple on the run!

Arthur Penn directed the crime thriller that put the blood and grit into Hollywood films forevermore: Bonnie & Clyde (1967). Penn uses squibs for blood and riddles bodies with bullets like audiences had never seen before Bonnie & Clyde. This is as influential as crime thrillers gets as Bonnie & Clyde influenced Badlands, Thelma & Louise, True Romance, and Natural Born Killers to name a few.

Arthur Penn's direction was the perfect director to balance character moments with gripping shootouts. I like how he just lets scenes play out. I love the banjo score theme song that is "Foggy Mountain Breakdown" by Flatt and Scruggs is the perfect mood setter for Bonnie & Clyde. It's high octane speed and playful tone fit the infamous crime duo's dramatic flair and vicious acts.

Bonnie Parker is depicted by Faye Dunaway as an alluring, if near sociopathic killer seeking love and dangerous. Dunaway is lovely and dreamy as Bonnie, but quickly all her sheen disappears as you realize she is just bored and needy. She uses Clyde for her own sick kicks to get an adrenaline rush out of robbery and murder of innocent people. Dunaway's greatest role will forever be as Bonnie because she charms you to distract you from her inner dissatisfaction.

Warren Beatty's portrayal of Clyde Barrow is strange as he's oddly likable for a serial killer and chronic bank robber. He's depicted as sensitive, yet absolutely capable and willing to commit murder at a moment's notice. Beatty is charming, but also brutal as he fires off countless rounds at the police and bystanders alike. I'd say Bonnie & Clyde is also Warren Beatty's best acting as he manages a nuanced portrayal of a complex mythic figure in criminal history.

I really enjoyed Gene Hackman's supporting role as Clyde's brother Buck Barrow. Hackman's eager and excitable personality gives Buck a magnetic persona. Estelle Parsons is hilarious as Blanche Barrow, Buck's hysterical and conservative wife. I appreciated Michael J. Pollard's portrayal of C.W. Moss as a dim witted, yet sincere youth bent on the excitement of crime. I am amazed by Dub Taylor's tough father figure Ivan Moss. Denver Pyle is solid and steadfast as Frank Hamer.

I must mention Gene Wilder gets a hilarious cameo as Eugene Grizzard in his film debut! Penn also cast a non-actress, Mabel Cavitt, as Bonnie's mother. She is apt as the nervous mother worried that her daughter will end up dead by the law if she continues her dangerous path.

In all, Bonnie & Clyde is an entertaining and thoughtful film well crafted by Arthur Penn.
I think a restoration is in order.

Still holds up after all these years. Great performances and chase scenes through rural Texas that hasn't changed much since the 1930s and of course one of the most emotionally violent greatest endings ever.
Great movie and you can take that to the bank!
greatest edited film of the 60s

A violent, rip-roaring yarn based on a true story about the infamous couple who went on a crime spree through Depression-era America before meeting a violent death at the hands of the law. I liked the anti-authority questioning of the status of the good guys and bad guys. And both the music and the fashion are first rate.

Producer/star Warren Beatty had to convince Warner Bros. to finance this film, which went on to become the studio's second-highest grosser. It also caused major controversy by redefining violence in cinema and casting its criminal protagonists as sympathetic anti-heroes. Based loosely on the true exploits of Clyde Barrow and Bonnie Parker during the 30s, the film begins as Clyde (Beatty) tries to steal the car of Bonnie Parker (Faye Dunaway)'s mother. Bonnie is excited by Clyde's outlaw demeanor, and he further stimulates her by robbing a store in her presence. Clyde steals a car, with Bonnie in tow, and their legendary crime spree begins. The two move from town to town, pulling off small heists, until they join up with Clyde's brother Buck (Gene Hackman), his shrill wife Blanche (Estelle Parsons), and a slow-witted gas station attendant named C.W. Moss (Michael J. Pollard). The new gang robs a bank and Clyde is soon painted in the press as a Depression-era Robin Hood when he allows one bank customer to hold onto his money. Soon the police are on the gang's trail and they are constantly on the run, even kidnapping a Texas Ranger (Denver Pyle) and setting him adrift on a raft, handcuffed, after he spits in Bonnie's face when she kisses him. That same ranger leads a later raid on the gang that leaves Buck dying, Blanche captured, and both Clyde and Bonnie injured. The ever-loyal C.W. takes them to his father's house. C.W.'s father disaproves his son's affiliation with gangsters and enters a plea bargain with the Texas Rangers. A trap is set that ends in one of the bloodiest death scenes in cinematic history. The film made stars out of Beatty and Dunaway, and it also featured the screen debut of Gene Wilder as a mortician briefly captured by the gang. Its portrayal of Bonnie and Clyde as rebels who empathized with the poor working folks of the 1930s struck a chord with the counterculture of the 1960s and helped generate a new, young audience for American movies that carried over into Hollywood's renewal of the 1970s. Its combination of sex and violence with dynamic stars, social relevance, a traditional Hollywood genre, and an appeal to hip young audiences set the pace for many American movies to come.

Warren Beatty & Faye Dunaway's chemistry & swag ensures this film's place  in film history as a classic caper.  Also historic as it was one of the first films to have protagonists who were anti-heroes - and the film was directed in a way that evoked empathy for them from the audience.

A film from 1967 that sort of paved the way for violent/adult Hollywood cinema for the years ahead.
I mean that films as iconic as The Godfather franchise, Unforgiven et al. might never have happened had it not been for the style of film exhibited here by director Arthur Penn.
The story is a 1930s set graphically violent depiction of American outlaws Bonnie Parker and Clyde Barrow played excellently by Faye Dunaway and Warren Beatty respectively.
It has elements of the Robin Hood story, showing them rob from mainly banks across several southern U.S. states.
It also shows the love that blossoms between the two (despite Clydes impotence).
The support cast provide excellent service including the two Genes, Hackman as Clydes brother Buck who faces a bloody death and the late Gene Wilder.
The film ends with the bloody death, I mean are sub machine guns necessary?
Excellent depiction and a forerunner for every outlaw film that was to follow.
A very memorable movie with great acting.
Good movie, great acting.
A stylish and engaging thriller of the New Hollywood era. Bonnie and Clyde has star-making performances setting the standard for violent Hollywood films to come

Ah, yes. The revered crime drama that not only set a new precedent for onscreen violence, but to this day still influences other crime dramas. And yes...it's still a damn good film that hasn't lost a bit of its luster since its release in 1967. As the title suggests, it follows the exploits of the notorious 1930's crime duo, Bonnie and Clyde, who along with other accomplices committed a string of bank robberies and numerous murders before being gunned down themselves. It's not exactly historically accurate, which comes with the territory regarding films about real people, but damn is it an entertaining film not just because of the terrific action sequences, but also because of the star power and chemistry of Warren Beatty and Faye Dunaway who elevate this film into something truly great. Their characters are bad people, but you will still enjoy their antihero personas whether it be in drama or just playful banter between them. The film is also a reflection of not just the turmoil of the Great Depression, but also the era the film itself released, giving viewers a morbid glimpse into freedom and bucking authority in a tumultuous time. Bonnie and Clyde still remains a certified classic and a must-watch for fans of crime dramas.
This movie is a masterpiece and a classic with great shootout scenes and two great lead actors and also a supporting  actor.

There isn’t much story in Bonnie and Clyde. That was perhaps the most surprising thing for me. I could have summarized everything I knew about Bonnie and Clyde in a sentence or two, and literally that was all that happened in the entire film. It’s a lot of robbing, a lot of hiding out, a bit of murdering, and a fitting end. But there’s not much more to the plot than that, aside from a few short detours along the way. In between all of the chaos there is a concerted effort put into establishing and developing characters, so that you will sympathize and find a way to care for these criminals. They have some interesting relationships within their gang, and each time a new member is brought into the fold they come with new personality and problems. That was nice because the growth of the gang was when we actually see some variety in the way the robberies play out. There were elements of the story that felt like a cautionary tale about the dangers that can come from being impulsive and living life on the edge instead of being content. However, I would have liked some kind of setup in the beginning that gave a stronger sense of why the two main characters were willing to go down this path instead of settling. As it is presented, we just see them meet, and within 5 minutes they have robbed someone and are fleeing for their lives. This works when you’re trying to establish how quickly they are swept up in this life, but it doesn’t help when we are expected to guess why they continue instead of getting out before things get worse. The same setup/backstory would be nice with each new member of the gang, because almost everyone seems to jump in just for the fun of it. The actors were all excellent, and that’s the biggest asset Bonnie and Clyde has going for it. When I would ordinarily hate these people because they are despicable murderers and robbers, I was able to connect with them a little more because they were played so well by actors I love. Even the small parts were great, including an amazing cameo from Gene Wilder. That’s what kept me engaged for the full movie, despite the fact that the actual plot was excessively repetitive and not all that interesting to me. I also thought the film did a poor job of trying to make you side with the gang. Sure we get to see them laughing, having fun, and occasionally sparing a life, but none of that was enough to justify anything they were doing. We never get justifiable motivations in Bonnie and Clyde, so that’s why I didn’t care about how it all ended.
An inaccurate depiction of the infamous duo and gang. Its strength comes from its romanticized story and intelligent script, its humor, and its envelope-pushing portrayal of violence on film.
Amazing. The entire film felt slow but it left a lasting impression on me.
Pretty great movie! I enjoyed it a lot! Great acting, great writing, great action. Just an overall great movie. Some parts dragged out, but that was my only complaint

You know, I had never heard of the film called Bonnie and Clyde and the fact that they both died in real life which is abrubtly shocking of me because everything about Bonnie and Clyde is memorable and in some film people say the name Bonnie and Clyde which is something that made me remember the two couple in general and the reason I said that is because this is a famous film in the decade. Warren Beatty and Faye Dunaway did a fantastic portrayal as Bonnie and Clyde and they go rob banks and drives away with Clyde's friend and his wife. The characters are portrayed very well and the cast in this is beautifully well done not to mention Gene Wilder is in this. He's in the film for the short time. I absolutely really love the cinematography in this. It is really fantastically shot. This is something that you will see in the cinema. It really is beautifully made and the acting from Warren Beatty and Faye Dunaway is so mesmerizing. And the ending of course is so amazing. Years ago people said it became one of the bloodiest death scenes in cinematic history. Britian's say these two are a bunch of idiots because they rob banks as the tagline says "We rob banks." As 60's cinema goes, this is an impeccable film with great directing and everything that defines the 60's in filmmaking. Bonnie and Clyde is a fantastic film and my new favourite film of all time.
Hit film with a very good cast has Bonnie & Clyde painted in more of the hero's role robbing banks and running from the law, which was unusual for the time.  Maintains interest.
It may not be completely historically accurate but it’s still an amazing feature

Warren Beatty and Faye Dunaway both give excellent performances and have great chemistry together.  They are also helped by a terrific supporting cast.  The movie also benefits from a well written script that keeps the audience hooked all the way from beginning to end.  It even has a few laughs here and there.  Most are provided by the late Gene Wilder in his feature film debut.  As great as the movie is, it does have a few minor flaws.  The basic story of this film is that Bonnie Parker and Clyde Barrow are actually very good people at heart who don't mean to be ruthless robbers and killers.  They were forced into their situation because the big, evil and heartless banks are hurting the little man and they want some payback.  There is the formulaic scene where as they are robbing a bank, they let an elderly farmer keep the money he was planning to deposit because they want that bank's money, not his.  We also get the scene where Clyde tells Bonnie's mother that they don't plan to lead a life of crime forever and hope to go straight.  In away these flaws show the film's influence in the sense that we see echoes of these plot devices in future movies.  The robbers don't want your money, they want the bank's money ("Heat" "Hell or High Water").  The banks with their evil ways of doing business force good people to do bad things (Again "Hell or High Water".).  The bad guys promise to to become legitimate very soon ("The Godfather".).  Despite these flaws, I say that this movie remains Warren Beatty and Faye Dunaway's crowning achievement in their celebrated careers and is well worth seeing.  Fifty years after the movie's original release, it is still just as powerful and entertaining now as it was then.

It's easy to understand why this is a classic: it's groundbreaking in its violence, unprecedentedly action-packed, and draws on many techniques that we had only seen in the French New Wave. But seriously, even films that it ultimately (if indirectly) spawned, like Badlands or The Sugarland Express, are better overall. This isn't true with all of them, in fact very few, but still worth noting. It's still really solid, with fantastic performances from adage Dunaway at her most stunning and Warren Beatty at his slickest, and great supporting roles. It has that great, bitingly funny edge to its depiction of America in the roaring 20's, which alternates between patriotic, shameless, and guilty.
The precursor to modern crime movies.

9.5 punt of 10:

Realistic, thrilling, and a great duo from Dunaway and Beatty, Bonnie and Clyde makes one of the quintessential gangster movies.

Though this film is perhaps more culturally significant than the film itself can really live up too it is still a solidly crafted, well acted and ultimately engrossing film. It also has great action with the violence being truly staggering in its brutality from a film from that time, a good score, looks great and has a few tense moments that are well conceived.
At the time I'm sure it was considered an outstanding movie, but it isn't one of the most exhilarating heist films.

I remember seeing the film for the first Around a decade ago as a teen & thought to myself there is something missing & I found it bizarre how I felt that exact feeling upon revisiting it early this week.

No doubt an interesting story of lawless & somewhat ruthless couple who meet in Texas in the depression & begin a tour across mid west robbing banks.

I found the structure & dialogue rather uneven & somewhat amateurish. May have had the impact it had due to the violence & intensity of the film. Interesting film but I found it inferior to other films of the genre. Fascinating to read that Warner Bros had so little faith in the film they allowed Warren Beatty to get 40% of Box Office...the film made over $60,000,000 in 1967!!

Just there names alone are badass Bonnie, Clyde. It was meant to be. That didn't even look like Faye when they first show her. Warren Beatty's a smooth dude. Kind of reminds me of Brando. Crazy to think that they just did whatever the hell they wanted to do. I guess back in those times early 1930's, you could get away with doing a lot more shit than today. It was reassuring to se them kind of get back at them by shooting the house and the bank sign up. Interesting to see that Clyde was asexual. He can't find it in him to have sex. Gene Hackman is always great to watch. He's got this unbelievable charm. That was pretty damn hilarious how Buck's wife just kept screaming while the law was shooting at them, but damn that was stupid of her. Clyde really knows how to shoot a gun. Holy shit, I can't believe the officer spit in Bonnie's face! She was just trying to be friendly. It's intersting how family got involved in there crimes like Clyde's brother. I love when there making faces through the car's window when they stop Eugene's car. It just show how lighthearted this movie is. That was real nice that they got to spend time with family. Even though they're crooks, they haven't forgotten the importance of family. That last look they gave each other before they got shot down was really something special. I like how abrupt the whole movie ended. 

This actually turned out to be a pretty damn funny movie. Really great movie!

Beautifully violent and sympathetically told, while it might not hold the bite it did when it was released only do to the massive influence it had on modern cinema, Bonnie and Clyde is a classic through and through, still moving and exciting to this day.

Arthur Penn directs this film very well peppering in some very cool shots (the first time Clyde shoots someone through the car window is awesome), but the best part of the film for me was how the relationship of Bonnie and Clyde was depicted. Warren Beatty and Faye Dunaway do such beautiful jobs of embodying these characters, who are very complicated in their own rights. Clyde does not want to have sex, Bonnie wants to do something other than be on the run forever, Clyde wants to look out for his family but at the same time Bonnie hates Blanche, etc. However, at the end of the day, these two really love each other more than anything and always come back to one another despite their conflicts, and the two leads portrayed that beautifully. Even though the film is about two bank robbers, it is a love story at its core.

This snappy, energetic and shockingly violent crime dramedy is wonderfully disorienting. A standout in the 60s film movement, with 2 fantastic lead performances, it's a sly and immensely entertaining critique of Western manhood, the American dream, and our futile search for fictional fame and Hollywood adventure.
Dull and flawed, Bonnie and Clyde is an overrated tale of a potential entertaining story - but it nonetheless brings some fine acting to compensate, especially Faye Dunaway's star turn.
Wonderful human love story. Overall very strongly holding story. Final part of the movie doesn't carry that well with some minor flaws.

Wholly satisfying and enjoyable movie going experience!

It hasn't aged as well as other great films from the 20th century, but it still a unique film in its own right, and quite deserving of its acclaim. It would be naïve to assume that this was just an objectively historical film. Instead, this is a film from the perspective of Bonnie and Clyde, and for something like that, it's actually pretty good. It's a fine example of a movie that takes its time before culminating in a memorable conclusion. The performances were quite realistic, given the context of the film's setting. The film's leading couple make for a rather effective pair of performers, and they seem to suit the role like the clothes they wear. The other characters tend to fade in and out of the background, but there really aren't any bad performances. The film's overall style does give off a kind of corny hillbilly feel, but thankfully, it doesn't happen all the time, and by the end, the mood of the film is irreversibly different. It's impossible to expect a film about two criminals to go without violence, and this film delivers it sparingly, before the film's famously violent climax. To be honest, nothing's wrong with this movie, but it's not as good as some of the other films that have been considered "classics". That said, however, it's still enjoyable in its own way.
This movie about doomed outlaws set a new bar for violence in American films.
its a cinematic experience to be cherished forever.
Was ok if not dated.
Loved it. Why do we care so much about Bonnie and Clyde? Because movies of this era made the effort to develop character.

It's good to be bad.  In the 1930's, Bonnie Parker (Faye Dunaway) and Clyde Barrow (Warren Beatty) teamed up, formed a gang and robbed banks across America.  This is the glamorized telling of the true story.  A lot of what makes this work as well as it does is the glorification of it all; it isn't really all that compelling of a story when you break it down, but when you have Beatty bringing the cool confidence and Dunaway flaunting sex appeal, it suddenly becomes accessible.  They make stealing cars and robbing banks seem appealing and like a blast, until that time arrives when it becomes overwhelming.  These are fully rounded characters that have a lot brewing underneath the surface, Bonnie especially; it is very interesting to see the way she reacts to the celebrity of it all, as it is such a drastic change of lifestyles.  They also share a great back and forth together, so when they first meet at the beginning of the story, you fully buy that they are hitting it off.  This may be more violent than you remember, and all of the gunplay leads to a very disturbing finale.  This is gritty, irresistible, and every note in between.
Great story line, cast, and photography. a depression era story about what desperate men will do.

Depression-era drama doesn't get more dastardly than Arthur Penn's audacious account of America's eponymous outlaws. The doomed lovers are played to tragic perfection by Warren Beatty and Faye Dunaway, but it's Penn's explosive direction that really steals the show, giving us a rip-roaring road movie with killer cross-cutting, a stunning soundtrack, gorgeous visuals AND Greek-grade emotional weight.
Not only is this a landmark movie in terms of cinematic violence, it's a through-and-through cinematic joy. And on top of that, it goes out with a real bang. A real BIG bang. Essential cinema.

I had no idea how handsome Warren Beatty was and still is. And he also made one hell of a performance in Bonnie and Clyde as Clyde. Faye Dunaway was good too.

(SPOILER) But the film can also teach you a lesson on getting carried away too quickly and too recklessly. You will get shot or sedated as the two in this film did.

Bonnie and Clyde falls into a group of films that have a major problem with it. It is based on true events meaning the outcome of the film has to be presented in a way which still keeps the audience interested even though they are aware of how it ends. The director manages to keep you watching by his well chosen cast. Warren Beatty and Faye Dunaway blend together well and are clearly having fun making it. Michael J. Pollard and Gene Hackman also give in fun performances.
Whilst the topic may be serious, it is presented here in a lighter manner. With nothing to have to think about, you can just enjoy a good old fashioned tale about a group of crooks travelling. The music featured may seem a bit distracting at first but as the films plays on you can see how that playful style works. Even with the shoot outs against the police, the film still finds time for some light humour. Gene Wilder turns up in a small part which is so humorous that you would surprise yourself that it actually happened. 
If I had to fault anything, then it would be the sudden stop at the end but this is nothing to fault the film with. Not too long and not too short, Bonnie and Clyde is a fun crime film that shouldn't be taken seriously.
Thrilling as hell and acted incredibly by Beatty, Dunaway, and the rest of the cast, this 60s classic has dated marvelously
One of the best American films ever, you can't beat Warren Beatty, Faye Dunaway, Gene Hackman, and Gene Wilder.

A true classic American film. From the brilliant script by Robert Benton and David Newman (with uncredited work by Robert Towne) to the French new wave influenced direction by Arthur Penn to  the gorgeous photography by Burnett Guffey  to the beautifully bleak production design by Dean Tavoularis, the film does not have a false note. The film is also greatly aided by a top notch cast, led by Beatty and Dunaway
Gloriously violent and extremely watchable, Bonnie and Clyde remains as entertaining as it was in 1967.

With new attention being drawn to the story, having spawned a History Channel miniseries, I thought it time to visit the acclaimed 1967 Bonnie and Clyde. Receiving large praise for its ingenuity and boldness, Arthur Penn's Bonnie and Clyde can rightly be called a classic. It's a film ahead of its time in approach, style, and execution. 

Watching Penn's Bonnie and Clyde, one might forget the way it redefined cinema for its time. This is a testament to how it has aged, being almost indistinguishable, and in many ways better, than modern films. The violence in this film is unflinching, not sanitized, but also not over-glamorized. The characterizations are surprisingly fresh and bold, casting two anti-heroes, both with deeply flawed personas and hints of even social taboos.

The film progresses at a brisk pace, yet never feels rushed. Penn guides the narrative in a way that feels organic and engaging, giving us necessary back-story, but never feeling the need to pander. The hallmark of the film is the central performances from Warren Beatty and Fay Dunaway. Both have a palpable chemistry, and both bring an enormous amount of charisma to the screen. Dunaway is perfect as the lonely, thrill-seeking, and self-destructive Bonnie Parker, and Beatty is superb as the vulnerable, yet dogged Clyde Barrow. These performances are set against strong action scenes, and within a script that emphasizes the characters, never attempting to force-thrills.

The one criticism of Penn's Bonnie and Clyde is the historical accuracy. To be sure, we expect liberties to be taken, and Penn's version is certainly more true than others, yet the film subscribes to some of the more dubious notions about the couple. The hints of Clyde's impotence, for example, seem to be a substitute for other questions regarding his sexuality, yet substance for this is lacking, with an actually and intense romantic relationship between the two being likely more accurate.

A strong film overall, largely befitting its classic status.

I particularly liked the bank robbery scene right after they picked up C.W. because it cut between the car chase and the people who were in the bank getting their picture taken by the papers and what not. I thought that was pretty clever; Bonnie and Clyde were hardly a mile away and they're getting interviewed! The most awkward scene was the first time they madeout. I guess it was supposed to be awkward to the viewer as well, but it was very strange in my opinion.

One of the greatest movies ever made, a milestone of American cinema detailing famous outlaws and their publicity from regular citizens. Broke the rules of violence shown on film (that stirred quite an amount of controversy in its day, and shocked audiences) but was raved by critics and now it's rightfully regarded as an American classic; many film buffs consider this to be the movie that was responsible for launching several careers. Estelle Parsons took home Best Supporting Actress Oscar although every performance is parallel. Burnett Guffey's audacious Cinematography also Won an Oscar for this masterpiece.  Director Arthur Penn's best film. Don't miss this!

"Bonnie and Clyde" is a conflictive, unsettling examination of sex and violence. The former is underplayed with thinly veiled innuendo (Bonnie excitedly touching Clyde's gun which he brandishes proudly; her post-coital cigarette comes after their first robbery); the latter is shocking even today. The signs of death hang heavy over the story, and even if you didn't know of the historic ends of the two real-life outlaws beforehand, it's very clear that this movie could only have ended one way. The famous final scene is simply jaw-dropping. This can be a difficult film to parse, particularly where it stands in regards to the moral lines that are drawn (we can't help but like and root for the gang at times; on the other hand, the film clearly portrays them as vicious and selfish, needing to be brought to justice). I imagine that's the point.Beatty and Dunaway are truly excellent, Gene Hackman is rowdy and real, and the short sequence featuring the screen-debut of Gene Wilder is maybe the best, funniest scene in the whole movie. Michael J. Pollard as C.W. also gives a fascinating and subtle performance. Estelle Parsons' (Oscar-winning) role as Blanche really got on my nerves, and I felt the film retread some character beats one too many times during the middle-third, but "Bonnie and Clyde" still stands as an incredibly visceral cinematic experience.
Maybe one day I will give this film another chance, and find that I was woefully unappreciative of it.  But not yet.
Loved  Beatty and Dunaway in this one. It struck me how graphic it was for a 1967 film. Really enjoyed it.
perfect storytelling, very agile directing, legendary editing, and star power that will live long into history.

Nice classic of the New Hollywood, but not my favorite. I guess it's well directed, but it lacks something really moving. Penn has done something really far better with "The Chase" or "Little Big Man".

This is the film that kicked off the Hollywood rennasaince of the 60's and 70's.  It was also a milestone because it was the first to heavily feature sex and violence. Faye Dunaway has never looked so good on film as she did in this American classic.

Had always heard about bonnie and clyde and was curious to see it. It's a movie unlike anyother. Comedic in parts and Dramatic and Violent in other parts. Brilliant performances from both actors portraying the historic characters. Ends with a bang... literally. Not exactly a feel good movie.

Before The Godfather, Bonnie and Clyde was a film that did not romanticize crime or glorify it as a fun way of life, but as a sad existence. This movie has many levels of depth and ideas, but the one that stuck to me most was the willingness to show that the gangster life is not one of getting money. Or getting to say "see?" and "ohh a wise guy eh?" but a story of real humans. Bonnie and Clyde do not intend to harm anyone, but they search for a better life in crime that they believe nothing else can offer. Instead, we see that they are in a downward spiral to a very gory and harrowing death. In a very stark and realistic moment, the camera does not give us a sweeping or epic shot of the car to suggest the ending of a legend. Rather, it shows us the death of two people who were searching for something and never found it. All we see are the sad expressions of the lawmen looking upon them. Not boastful or prideful in their accomplishment in ending the spree of some extremely deadly and famous criminals, but mournful and reflective. This shows us that Bonnie and Clyde were not criminals who should be cheered over after they've been killed, but people like us who searched for the wrong thing. Near the end of the film, Bonnie says "You know what, when we started out, I thought we was really goin' somewhere. This is it. We're just goin', huh?" The 60's people would like us to believe this is a story of two gangsters who shun authority, live life on their own terms and do what they want.  When in reality, when you shun all of your authority and just do what you want, you're not finding the answers. You're just goin'.
So much blood but so much fun to watch.

Solid crime movie featuring two of the world's most notorious bank robbers. The acting is spot-on (apart from Estelle Parsons who I COULDN'T STAND) and the final scene really pushed the boundaries back then for violence...wow!

A highly romanticized and fictionalized version of the story of Bonnie and Clyde. I must have seen this movie a hundred times growing up. It is true that the real Bonnie Parker was a waitress in West Dallas, Texas when she ran into Clyde Barrow. They say women are attracted to bad boys, but Bonnie took that to the extreme as she left home to join Clyde on a multi-state Robbing and Murder Spree. That eventually ended in the two of them being shot to death along a country road.

There's nothing quite like it and there never will be.  It stands the test of time.  I mean good god, this movie was extraordinarily well made, and I don't give a shit how historically accurate it is.  This one was about the characters within the legend and Arthur Penn made a masterpiece.  It even has Estelle Parsons as maybe the most annoying character ever put on film, yet it works (but I'll be damned if I didn't wanna see that whiny cunt get a mouthful of buckshots).  I really did forget that this is one of the greatest films of all time.
It's a good movie, good acting, good script, the action scenes were cool. Very good movie to watch

Bonnie and Clyde is a violent and in a way a romance, at times the film really does glorify violence in which when the film was released was controversial due to showing the impact of what being shot is really like compared to films which would mask violence using editing techniques.
The film also glorifies what love is, it's that first encounter when you fall in love. The film is also quite erotic using personifications and the film is shot in such a way that resembling French new wave, when Bonnie and Clyde first take a walk into town and figure each other out, Clyde pulls out a gun using extreme close ups of Bonnie stroking the gun while she fondles with a bottle around her lips, you only need to add things up to put things into a sexual connotation.
Although the film seems a mythical legend an awful lot the film is based on reality, a beautiful couple who rob banks and are on the run. The film has been referenced so much to the point that i knew the story of Bonnie and Clyde before i even saw the film.
What the actors performances give to the film is in reality the way story's are skewed, we see peoples lives and personalitys without judging them. Warren Beatty is a man who looks almost comical, while Bonnie is innocent and wants more in her life than been a waitress, the two were destined to meet.
Overall Bonnie and Clyde is a film based on two principles love and violence, we as humans have no more response to these two emotions. In a way i think the film is quite funny at times, it is great to watch the character development, Bonnie becomes more confident and also so does Clyde when robbing the banks. Although the film is often referenced today, the film then also references things like DW Griffith with the wacky car chases and cross cutting between two sets of different things going on like when a bank is robbed and they are been chased, the witnesses in the bank are glorifying the gang.
Quite the shocking ending, but overall a very entertaining movie.
This is a great movie! I first saw this in the theater in 1967 as a kid.  This movie change everything.

The film that ushered in the New Wave of American cinema and what some would consider the greatest decade of cinema to date: the 1970's. Basically the period between 1967-1979 (though I would end it around 1977 as that is when Star Wars came along and changed cinema once again for better or worse). The acting style of the film was very original in its day and the subject matter (specifically the final moments) were quite the controversy. It remains a benchmark of American cinema and a requirement for all film lovers.

There's no denying the film's importance in the landscape of cinema. It's a well crafted tale of lawless lovers out for a thrill with an ending that leaves you breathless. Some elements hold up better than others, but it's still clearly evident why it captivated the world. Bonnie and Clyde's chemistry and carefree spirit are irresistible, and we're more than happy to tag along on this joyride.
Entertaining. An ending I would've not expected. Bloody.
This is a pretty dark film, and leads to one of the most brutal deaths I've ever seen from a 1960's film.
God damn magic on screen. One of the best bank robber films I've ever seen. So good, in fact, that you of course want to see the "bad guys" win. Awesome film.
